text: I'm Matt gross the frugal traveler for
the New York Times / 13 weeks this
summer I trekked across Europe on a
modern and frugal version of the Grand
Tour we think we know Europe but on my
own grand tour this summer I was
surprised to discover that Europe still
holds surprises the cultures and
languages of England France Italy
Germany and beyond have dominated the
world for most of the last 500 years
they don't call Europe the old world for
nothing and since the 18th century the
Grand Tour has been an exploration of
what exactly makes this old world old I
got around Europe mostly by train
sometimes by bus took a few flights took
a few fairies rode a moped
I even hitchhiked across Northern Cyprus
see your hitchhiking face yeah I do this
would totally blew me away about
hitchhiking in Northern Cyprus what is
how easy it was in four days I got 14
rides never had to wait more than 15
minutes and the people who picked me up
were the most generous people I met on
the trip what continued to amaze me was
that in many of the places I went people
were willing to give things away
completely for free in mountain on the
French Riviera I wound up talking to a
restauranteur and asking to film in his
kitchen without telling him I was from
the New York Times and out of nowhere he
offered me a free meal if you promise to
send me a cassette of this video you can
come back tonight and I'll treat you to
dinner on me mother go I kept meeting
people who really cared about the places
they lived in Vilnius Lithuania I met
yiannis Guinness who by sheer
coincidence had just gotten his
professional city guides license so it's
it's good when you're on your third is
to brush up your memory a little bit to
learn about the building's you pass
every day and of course about this
history
I met some real characters and right
from the beginning to on the boat over
from Dover to Calais I met Benoit wazi
who invited me to an opening at his art
gallery mmm if you stay some someday and
friends I open them a new exhibition
originally the Grand Tour was all about
meeting artists and exploring high
culture there I was doing it without
even trying this is the capital cinema
an abandoned open-air movie theater that
now hosts a population of rabbits and
arty events this one was for either a
new monthly newspaper in comic book form
the 18th century grand tourists were
obsessed with art they would Commission
paintings they would buy sculptures and
then they would haul everything back to
England with them in Calais in the
lighthouse I met a woman who is an
amateur sketch artist I'm supposed to
send her this photo she will draw it and
she'll send it back to me this drawing
will be my entire collection as rooted
as places like rome and romania are in
the past they're adapting in startling
ways to shifting borders new waves of
immigration and a wholesale redefinition
of what it means to be European in the
first place in Calais I met a handful of
refugees it made me realize how lucky I
am to be able to travel for fun rather
than out of necessity and on a budget
that to them would be staggering Roshan
from Sri Lanka and his friend Achmed
from Somalia let me back to their home
in the place people call the jungle
their lives are about as hard as you can
imagine I just wanted my mom and dad I
am fine I'm surviving
I really thought that I knew Europe but
after 13 weeks of new places new people
and new experiences the old world
doesn't really seem so old plus I only
visited 16 countries out of the 48
that's how many left to explore for the
New York Times this is matt gross the
frugal traveler
